Acquit.origin: [Old French acquiter to pay off, absolve, acquit, from a- , prefix marking causation + quite free (of an obligation)]

ac·quit·ting.definition: [Old Frenchto pay off, absolve, acquit, from, prefix marking causation +free (of an obligation)]to discharge completely

sub_terms.a: to release from liability for a debt or other obligation usually used in agreements [forever release, , and discharge each other]
sub_terms.b: to absolve (a criminal defendant) of a charge by judicial process
sub_terms.c: to clear of wrongdoing [the fact…does not them of misrepresentation ", 694 P.2d 540 (1985)"]to absolve a defendant of criminal liability [must if any reasonable doubt existed ", 638 N.E.2d 20 (1994)"] compare
